Module WitchHunt
Package fr.sos.witchhunt.model.players

Class CPUPlayer

java.lang.Object
fr.sos.witchhunt.model.players.Player
fr.sos.witchhunt.model.players.CPUPlayer
All Implemented Interfaces:
PlayerDisplayRequester, Resettable, Visitable
public final class CPUPlayer extends Player

This class represents a CPU-controlled player.

It overrides all of Player's abstract methods.

All choices are made using a strategy, which behaves as an artificial intelligence with a behavior that is suited for specific situations. CPU-controlled players regularly choose one Strategy among others depending on the situation (their position in the ranking, the leading player's score, their number of cards, their score...). This is an implementation of the Strategy design pattern.

See Also:
  • Player
  • PlayStrategy
  • chooseStrategy()

  • Field Details

    • chosenStrategy

      private PlayStrategy chosenStrategy

      The current strategy chosen by the CPUPlayer.

      Updated by chooseStrategy(), which is called regularly (on turn start, on round end, on accusation, when defending...

      The initial strategy, chosen when the match starts, is GropingStrategy.

      A strategy is an instance of a class implementing PlayStrategy, an interface specifying all sorts of choices an AI must be capable to make.

      See Also:
      • PlayStrategy

    • oldStrategy

      private PlayStrategy oldStrategy
      See Also:
      • chooseStrategy()

    • knownWitch

      private Player knownWitch

      A reference to a player known as a Witch.

      When using the Hunt! effect of card The Inquisiton, CPU-controlled players look at their target's identity and will remember it if it happens to be Witch. That known witch will then become a high-priority target when choosing a player to accuse or choosing a player to hunt.

      See Also:
      • lookAtPlayersIdentity(Player)
      • choosePlayerToAccuse()
      • chooseTarget(List)
      • Identity
      • TheInquisiton

    • actionsDelay

      private int actionsDelay

      A short delay is added between all actions performed by CPU Players to let the users keep the track of what happens during their turns.

      Expressed in milliseconds.

      public void reset()
      Resets the player and lets them choose a strategy. The chosen strategy holds sway on the next round's chosen identity, this is why it is important to choose a strategy even at the end of a round.

      public final void chooseIdentity()
      Chooses the player's identity for the current round, based on the chosen strategy.

      Also requests for the display of a screen notifying the view that the CPUPlayer has chosen their identity.

    • beHunted

      public void beHunted()

      When targetted by a Hunt! effect, chooses a strategy and updates its behavior.

      This allows the CPU Player to adapt their behavior to their situation when they are targetted by a hunt effect, as their situation can have changed between their turn and that attack.

      Overrides:

    • chooseAnyCard

      public RumourCard chooseAnyCard(RumourCardsPile rcp, boolean seeUnrevealedCards)

      Chooses the best card (revealed or not) within a pile of Rumour cards, based on the chosen strategy.

      The chosenStrategy is beforehand updated in order to have the most accurate possible behavior.

      It is possible to keep secret the properties of unrevealed cards to the chosenStrategy.

      Specified by:
      chooseAnyCard in class Player
      Parameters:
      rcp - The pile of Rumour cards within which a card must be chosen.
      seeUnrevealedCards - If this boolean is true, the chosenStrategy will be able to access the information of unrevealed cards as well to make their choice.
      Returns:
      The best Rumour card within the given pile, according to the chosen strategy.
      See Also:
      • Player.chooseAnyCard(RumourCardsPile, boolean)
      • PlayStrategy::selectBestCard(RumourCardsPile, boolean)
      • PlayStrategy::updateBehavior(boolean, Identity, RumourCardsPile)

    • lookAtPlayersIdentity

      public Identity lookAtPlayersIdentity(Player target)

      Sneakily looks at a given player's Player.identity.

      Called when using card The Inquisiton.

      CPU-controlled players will remember the target's reference if their identity happens to be Witch, making them a high-priority target to accuse or to hunt.

      Overrides:
      lookAtPlayersIdentity in class Player
      Parameters:
      target - The player of which the identity is going to be looked at.
      Returns:
      The targetted player's identity

    • revealOrDiscard

      public DefenseAction revealOrDiscard()

      Chooses an action between revealing your identity and discarding a Rumour card from your hand, based on the chosen strategy.

      Called when targetted by the Ducking Stool card's Hunt! effect.

      If the player has no cards to discard, or if they are already revealed, they will directly choose their only option and will request the view to display suitable screens.

      Specified by:
      revealOrDiscard in class Player
      Returns:
      Either DefenseAction.REVEAL or DefenseAction.DISCARD
      See Also:
      • PlayStrategy::revealOrDiscard(Identity, RumourCardsPile)
      • DefenseAction
      • Player.revealIdentity()
      • Player.discard(RumourCard)
      • DuckingStool

    • chooseStrategy

      public void chooseStrategy()

      Chooses a strategy based on the player's current situation.

      If the player is in relatively good position (score close to 5, is leading or has many cards), the player will opt for an offensive strategy, allowing them to take more risks, Player.hunt() more often, to focus the weakest players, to value the cards with offensive effects and causes them to be more likely to choose to play as villagers.

      If the game is tied, if the leading players are far above in score, if this player has no cards left, if this player plays as a witch and is not close to victory, they will opt for a defensive strategy, making them more likely to play as witches, stingier on cards and valuing cards based on their Witch? effect above all, focus the leading players (or players with no cards left), and more likely to choose to play as witches.

      By default at game start, or if they are not in a situation where they can choose to play offensively or defensively, the player will opt for a groping strategy, with which the chosen identity and the accused players are chosen randomly, the cards are considered for their overall value, and with which the player tries to keep their best cards for later, when he can choose a more defined strategy.

      The chosenStrategy will then be used for making every choice the CPU-controlled player has to make.

      The chosen strategy's behavior is then updated to actualize the value given to each card. It will be regularly updated afterwise (before every choice).

      See Also:
      • PlayStrategy
      • chosenStrategy
      • OffensiveStrategy
      • DefensiveStrategy
      • GropingStrategy
